comments.commentBody:
America hasn't lost a "war" since Vietnam, Mark: we've won them ALL, and by historically impressive margins by the world's most professional military (by far). What we've lost, largely by amateurish decisions made by non-military leaders, have been lengthy occupations with nation-building as the goal, a mission our military doesn't understand and that our own nation stinks at.

We've grown wiser about our limitations. If Mattis and Trump keep our military focused on military and not global social objectives, they'll do us as proud as they always have.

The most important space we have to worry about is the large quantity between the president-elect's ears. He's appointing fundamentalists, zealots and science deniers to important positions, not to discover the truth, but merely to ensure that inconvenient scientific truths don't prevent businesses from belching billions of tons of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.

It's pointless to try to bring these people down to earth with rational discourse, evidence or scientific facts, because that's not what buoys them up. More than forty percent of Americans think that the earth is no more than 10,000 years old. That level of ignorance may explain how the president-elect got elected, but it also explains why it's so easy for ideologues in Congress to trivialize and demean scientific endeavors.

Besides, what does NASA know about anything? It's just a bunch of eggheads wasting money on worldwide communication satellites, global positioning systems and predicting dangerous weather. Who needs all that when you've got the Farmers' Almanac?

It's not much in the way of consolation, but given the political powder keg of religious wars, terror attacks, dismantling the social safety net and destroying affordable health care, we're likely to extinguish ourselves as species before the seas boil from runaway global warming.

But it is ironic that the president who promised to drain the swamp might just help to create one big enough to engulf the entire world.

.
Gemli,

You'd think that almost all well-versed Bible readers might - at some point in their lives - have come across the story of Noah and his Ark (Chapters 6-8 of Genesis):

Basically it's God's (or Mother Nature's) retribution for the bulk of humanity's wicked ways, to wit:

And God looked upon the Earth, and, behold, it was corrupt; for all flesh had corrupted His way upon the Earth. [KJV: 6:12]

Humans are so very good at looking in the mirror and not seeing themselves.
Thanks for the humor, Gail. And Frieda and Trump differ in one important respect. I would rather cast my vote for her.
Frieda does not lie. Dogs just don't have it in them.

At some point in near future when Trump performs action that presents an existential threat to the Republic:

Them:"Why didn't we see this coming"

Us: "We did"

Seems like we're living in the Alternate Universe episode from the Seinfeld show!  Sadly, this isn't make believe and change agent or not there is a protocol for U.S. diplomacy.  Trump's going to start a war.
Well he did not go to war because he had a flat foot or broken nail, or was orange or yellow. When the war starts he can send one of his kids.
Trump's voters, who lost millions of jobs to Chinese child labor, environmental policies, etc. are utterly unconcerned with the "affront" to the totalitarian dictatorship of the Politburo.

That's excellent that Trump's supporters are not concerned with the affront to a country with four times the population of the U.S., which holds $1.24 trillion of our debt, which has nuclear weapons.

Trade war? Debt default? Nuclear war? Feh, Donald will take them down a peg or two. Or get us killed. One or the other.
...and it was their American CEOs who decided to maximise profits for the investor class on the backs of the jobless. Credit where credit is due.
Clearheaded:  The so-called experts put us in this position.

Nobody should read too much into any of these things except the fact that voters have elected a total amateur. Trump really has no clue about how diplomacy works, no clue about the nuances and subtleties of international relations and relationships, no clue about what's happening around the world.

Fasten your seat belts folks, it's only going to get crazier.

While President Obama is still our President, shouldn't the White House be informed about these phone calls and tweets. Does Mr. Trump really believe he can bypass daily briefings, ignore the State Dept. , the Pentagon, the CIA , etc and effectively run the government as if it a private company. Or is he a very shrewd and wily flame thrower who hopes to continually distract us so that we will forget we do not know what the actual business dealings of Mr. Trump and his Trump Organization are. God bless Republican Abe Lincoln who said you cannot fool all of the people all of the time.

Unfortunately, 60 million American fools voted for this nightmare. How embarrassing that we have more than a dozen people who could possibly think that this person is fit to lead. His incompetence has been more than transparent.

Based on his own statements, Trump's got a really good brain and he watches TV.

What more do you need to lead the richest, most powerful nation on the globe?

Taiwan is a functioning democratic republic. It belongs in the community of nations, and would be a worthy US ally. The Taiwan that President Carter left behind was a one-party state, but that has changed, and so too then should its treatment.

The only reason Taiwan is not a full-fledged nation is that a bullying, sulking, undemocratic China wants another province. Look what China has done to political liberties in Hong Kong. Why should we offer China any succor, except out of a fear of conflict? The liberal democratic world should not be proud of how it kowtows to China's unreasonable position. Trying to avoid conflict with a bully often ends poorly.

Whether Trump took a step in this direction out of calculation, ignorance, or purpose, I don't know. But we ought not lose sight of the fact that Taiwan deserves better than the halfling status we have provided it.
Amen!

There are reasons we have had this policy 30 plus years.  Trump's action may result in the invasion of Taiwan by China or a more bellicose attitude and we could be faced with an intervention and or possible war with China.  Conversely, this policy has allowed Taiwan a modicum of independence from China and a solid democracy that only exists because all of the preceding presidents' understanding regardless of party.

You need to realize your (our?) version of history is not the shared by everyone, most importantly, China. It views Taiwan as a province of China. There is no discussion on this issue from the Chinese point of view. None. Regardless of how democratic Taiwan is today. For the US/West to promote and/or actively seek to change Taiwan's status is a profoundly serious position. Like it or not, this die was cast when Nixon made his choice to pivot towards China.

From China's perspective even a hint of backing an independent Taiwan would be like China backing Mexico's claim to Texas. Not something that would sit well with America (well, okay some people might not mind a Texas-less US.)

I have never felt so helpless in my life. We are on the brink of disaster from every perspective with president loonie tunes at the helm.

We can't let this happen. It's just that at this point we must wait till this idiot really creates an impeachable action.

We must speak out. Act.

I doubt I will agree with much that the President elect does. On China maybe not. NTR for the PRC has been a disaster for the US. We run a large deficit and it is mainly with the PRC and has a negative impact on the Balance of Payments. It is due to policy choices. We run a 3 to 1 deficit against us in trade. We allow critical goods to be manufactured outside the US including important pharmaceuticals. It is time to reverse that process. It will be a painful transition but one well worth it. Along the way perhaps the US government will again take up the cause of the Tibetan people which seems to have been shuffled off.  Aside from which given our ongoing sale of complex arms to Taiwan the whole thing is basically bad theater. Taiwan is not going to be part of the PRC in any near or long term.
Totally agree. Thanks

Nixon went to China first. The United Nations recognizes one China only. That is also the United States policy. Taiwan still calls itself "The Republic of China", the international community does not. So that is why this could potentially create a diplomatic crisis. However, the US has good relations with Taiwan and so does China. A lot of commerce between Taiwan and China and visits by people on both sides. Things were fine as they were. No need to stir the pot.

Trump has not as yet been sworn in as Pres. of the USA. He may be Pres Elect., but he is not The Pres. He has no business or right to  meddle in our international affairs until he takes office. For all he knows, he may be upsetting some very important negotiations that may come to fruition within the coming month. He has been overstepping the bounds of a Pres. in waiting.

Try stop history now.
Congratulations
He really doesn't know, since he refuses to attend intelligence briefings!

I a man amazed at the people who seem to think that being a bull in a china shop, as Trump is doing, is the proper approach, and the Devil take the hindmost.

One can gratuitously insult others. That is always one's prerogative. However, there may be nasty consequences which one has to be willing to deal with.

All the "stick it to 'me" types need to accept the fall K that will be coming back, thanks to this undisciplined buffoon.

I don't think there is a way to put a good face on this. We just elected the Ugly American as President. At best he will be an embarrassment. At worst? I am afraid to imagine it.

In any case we should expect a surge of anti-American feeling around the world. Maybe he is ok with that. Strongmen find external threats very useful.

How clueless can someone be? Obama brought about a surge in anti-American feeling not to mention several terrorist attacks in the last few years. From Benghazi to San Bernardino to Egypt to Ft Hood to Ukraine to NY/NJ, it's been one disaster after another. The Chinese themselves have underplayed this, so stow your childish rhetoric.

If you want to engage in name-calling, there are other forums for you to post in. I think you just don't remember how the US was viewed back in 2008 when Obama was elected. If there was one thing he did accomplish was to restore our good name in the world. No, he did not make terrorism go away, and could not effectively extricate us from the morass in Iraq created by the Bush. Blaming the onset of chronic instability in the Muslim world on Obama is just bizarre, and no, there is no magic wand an American President can wave to make it go away.

And don't congratulate yourself that the Chinese are not escalating this, which is due to two factors:

- Trump isn't President yet, and
- They and the rest of the world are learning that he is just a blowhard and not to be taken seriously.

The thing we really have to worry about is how Trump will respond to the lack of respect he is about to get from the rest of the world. Not everyone is going to flatter him (unless of course they have business interests to promote).
What an arrogant, uninformed, careless idiot is this, our soon to be President. So much for rising to the honor and dignity of the office he's soon to hold. What a complete disaster

Trump's ego has gotten bigger, if that's possible, as a result of winning the election.  The flimflam president to be has already made a faux pas with China.  He's so full of himself that he thinks he can smooth talk and bamboozle foreign leaders. I wish the future Secretary of State good luck, because he will be putting out lots of fires that Trump started.
And why does China get to decide who our President talks to?  Please explain.
I'll let you figure it out. But it seems that we need China a lot more as an influence in that area versus Taiwan. They have more power. It's called geopolitical.
I'd bet that the conversation included Trump's interest in building a Trump Hotel or Trump Tower in Taiwan. Of course no conflict of interest in Trump's mind.

If you follow our president-elect as closely as you should, you surely remember that he told the NYT last week that, "The law's total on my side. The president can't have a conflict of interest."

And that reminded me of Nixon - remember he said, "If the president does it, it's not illegal."?
The idiot speaks again and we all suffer again. How is it possible that instead of America moving forward it is going back to the twelve century? Ignorance prevails in our country, no doubt about it.
Thought you were talking about Hillary voters.

This is highly likely to provoke a Chinese attack on Taiwan. Trump must be either blocked by the Electoral College -- as is their duty under the Constitution -- or immediately impeached upon taking office. Even if each of these blunders has only a 5% chance of starting a major regional war, Trump is producing them at a rate of several per week. It won't take long until a major war, entailing a serious interruption of international trade along with massive destruction and mass deaths, is a near certainty.

Are you sure your name isn't really Chicken Little?

The presidential electors will not be picking Hillary Clinton. Donald Trump will not be impeached. There is no war on the horizon. China will not be attacking Taiwan. And finally, the sky is not falling. Really, it is not.

For the readers who support Mr. Trump's action in this case, there are two possible options here: (1) Mr. Trump acted this way because he had no idea of our current policy and the potential implications of his act. In this case you would be supporting that we base our policies on utter ignorance, which does not sound like a recipe for success.

Or (2) he was aware of our current foreign policy on the issue (held by the last six presidents, including Saint Ronald Reagan), and decided to undermine the position of the current Department of State and a sitting president (yes, we elect our presidents for full four-year terms, not three and 10 months; Mr. Obama is still the POTUS), while he is still not the one in charge; which would probably fall under the Logan Act (1 Stat. 613, 18 U.S.C. § 953).

And that's basically it, unless somebody else can add a third option here. A reckless ignoramus or a traitor. Your pick.

Trump was born into great wealth on this Universe's Earth. He did not rise to anything. He started his life at the top. Maybe that was not the case in your alternate reality. How did you create a pathway between our Universes? Your insight would prove invaluable to my team's research efforts.

'A common man', a gentlemen farmer'.
Honestly that is the most ridiculous thing I have heard about trump
In this entire campaign.
Hahahahahahaha

Trump doesn't need to be a career politician. He does need to study and prepare. It would help if he had some basic knowledge. But no -- He's willfully ignorant and shoots from the hip. What you see is what you get. There's no evidence of understanding or deep intelligence. He's not the gentleman farmer you describe.
Congress can't impeach a president-elect. Impeachment is to remove someone from office due to grave misconduct.  He has to be sworn in first.

To jump the gun and blunder into a "policy" is folly. New policy needs to be carefully considered before careful diplomatic steps are taken.

That's not what occurred here!

Trump is causing chaos on a daily basis. Every day he gives further evidence of a temperament so unfit for the presidency as to defy belief. And every day I wake up dumbfounded yet again.

Please, Electors, save us from this destabilizing chaos!

The worrying thing is this. Trump thinks he's a hot shot negotiator, a superstar businessman, a problem solver, a top-dog to whom people will listen, after all, he's a billionaire, TV personality and the President-elect of the United States of America. But what does the rest of the world think? More than half of his own country already thinks he's a conman, does the President of Taiwan or Pakistan really take him any more seriously? Or do they know that he has no foreign policy experience. Do they know that he's likely to take their flattering phone calls and in doing so make statements that will anger and create divisions with these countries adversaries? It's sad to see, but the world knows Donald Trump's flaws and they are already using them against him.

Very clearly: the rest of the world greatly disliked Hillary Clinton, but very decisively wanted her to win, bar a number of rogue agents such as Putin.

As such, Trump's blundering over Taiwan (referred to afterwards with his usual childish blistering and posturing) sets a tone for his likely presidency: either Trump, and his so-called experts, have considerably less Real Politik world knowledge than ordinary people (that is, ordinary people out here in the actual real world), or he's indifferent to America's longstanding interactions with the rest of the world, and to continuing the 'long game' interests of America's presidents stretching back to the early years of the 20th Century.

Indeed, given emerging reports of Trump's casino/business explorations and nosing about in Taiwan as recently as just last month, November, a sharp-witted citizen might wonder just how innocently hands-off such a phonecall from Taiwan's premiere might be - but then, we've seen firsthand how little many of our American friends seem to be bothered about, or knowledgeable about, that odious and profoundly dangerous man.

To quote Mister Spock: "Only Nixon could go to China." One wonders if our Vulcan neighbours are making up a new saying about Trump and Taiwan...

We may just get a "Seven Days in May" scenario but it will be the Generals who are the sane ones. Following the Reagan and George W. Bush game plan with tax cuts and more military spending, deficits will increase immediately and  we'll be in a recession in a few months and possibly a Depression by October. This is in the stars because the last time the Republicans won the White House, House of Representatives and Senate was the election in November 1928. They will continue to steal from Social Security and Medicare (3 trillion already stolen) and call for cuts so the neocons can have another war.  "Fool me once, shame on you.  Fool me twice, shame on me.  You are not going to pull this a third time."
As a recent Baby Boomer retiree  your points here make my blood run cold.
